column4: if firefox says for an URL "Server not found" does it mean the remote site is down or does it mean that there is some issue with the DNS lookup?
Not found generally means the DNS lookup didn't return a valid address. Try the command 'host some.host.com' on terminal.
Halitech: sheep: thanks, not able to access www.cs.ubc.ca today
they seem to have a problem with their DNS server.
thanks for verifying that for me

That is something outside the capabilities of a shell. You might manage to do something like that with chroot, or AppArmor, but generally this isn't an easy thing to do. Why do you want to do t his, anyway?
Normal Linux file permissions restrict writing to homedir and /tmp, anyway.
trying to run a program that is possibly rouge
Writing an AppArmor profile might help.
so, I should create another user and run it as that?
Yes, another user would be the easiest way to do it. (You could even try using the existing one -- 'nobody')
didn't know of nobody, does it have a random password or something? why is this user there? for temporary user needs?
It doesn't have any password. It is mostly designed for daemons. (Though most of them get their own accounts nowadays.)
You might try 'sudo -u nobody -i' to get a shell running as 'nobody'.
thanks, that worked out very well. I was probably being too careful.
Do you have DejaVu fonts? (If I recall correctly, DejaVu ones are just extended Bitstream Vera.)
i have those, let me try using them
